facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 890 of 1961 of Murder Reference No. 74 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special Leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 890 of 1961 of Murder Reference No. 74 of 1961. Jai Gopal Sethi, C. L. Sareen and R. L. Kohli, for appellant.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by the Sessions Judge, Patiala, of an offence under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gurdev Singh and sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant was companyvicted by the Sessions Judge, Patiala, of an offence under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gurdev Singh and sentenced to death. The Punjab High Court dismissed his appeal and companyfined the sentence of death.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed his appeal and confirmed the sentence of death.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab High Court dismissed his appeal and companyfined the sentence of death. The present appeal is on the strength of special granted by this Court. The prosecution case is that at about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960 when Gurdev Singh was passing the tea-stall of Cbaran Singh, number far from the companyrts at Barnala on a motor cycle, the appellant Sewa Singh, who was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him.

facts.text: Present appeal on the strength of special leave granted by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is on the strength of special granted by this Court. The prosecution case is that at about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960 when Gurdev Singh was passing the tea-stall of Cbaran Singh, number far from the companyrts at Barnala on a motor cycle, the appellant Sewa Singh, who was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him.

facts.text: At about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960 Gurdev Singh was passing the tea-stall of Charan Singh, not far from the courts at Barnala on a motor cycle.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that at about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960 when Gurdev Singh was passing the tea-stall of Cbaran Singh, number far from the companyrts at Barnala on a motor cycle, the appellant Sewa Singh, who was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him.

facts.text: Appellant Sewa Singh was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant Sewa Singh, who was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him. Gurdev Singh was hit on the right side of his chest and died instantaneously. The appellant and one Gogar Singh, who was with him, ran away.

facts.text: Gurdev Singh was hit on the right side of his chest and died instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: Gurdev Singh was hit on the right side of his chest and died instantaneously. The appellant and one Gogar Singh, who was with him, ran away. The accused pleaded number guilty.

facts.text: The appellant and one Gogar Singh, who was with him, ran away.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and one Gogar Singh, who was with him, ran away. The accused pleaded number guilty. It was number disputed that Gurdev Singh had died of a gun shot injury at the time and place as alleged.

facts.text: Accused pleaded not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The accused pleaded number guilty. It was number disputed that Gurdev Singh had died of a gun shot injury at the time and place as alleged. It was satr- entiously companytended, however, that he was number the culprit.

facts.text: It was not disputed that Gurdev Singh had died of a gun shot injury at the time and place as alleged.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed that Gurdev Singh had died of a gun shot injury at the time and place as alleged. It was satr- entiously companytended, however, that he was number the culprit. According to the prosecution this occurrence was witnessed by Charan Singh, the owner of the shop and Mukhtiar Singh, a Student, and Bakhtawar Singh, the two persons who were having tea in the shop.

facts.text: Contended that he was not the culprit.

anchor.surface_text: It was satr- entiously companytended, however, that he was number the culprit. According to the prosecution this occurrence was witnessed by Charan Singh, the owner of the shop and Mukhtiar Singh, a Student, and Bakhtawar Singh, the two persons who were having tea in the shop.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Charan Singh, owner of the shop, Mukhtiar Singh a student, and Bakhtawar Singh, the two persons who were having tea in the shop.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution this occurrence was witnessed by Charan Singh, the owner of the shop and Mukhtiar Singh, a Student, and Bakhtawar Singh, the two persons who were having tea in the shop. At the trial Charan Singh denied any knowledge as to who had fired the shot and was declared hostile by the prosecution.

facts.text: At the trial Charan Singh denied any knowledge as to who had fired the shot and was declared hostile by the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial Charan Singh denied any knowledge as to who had fired the shot and was declared hostile by the prosecution. The other two witnesses gave evidence that they saw the present appellant, who was known to them from before, firing the shot from a double barrel gun.

facts.text: Other two witnesses gave evidence that they saw the present appellant, who was known to them from before, firing the shot from a double barrel gun.

anchor.surface_text: The other two witnesses gave evidence that they saw the present appellant, who was known to them from before, firing the shot from a double barrel gun. Their evidence was believed by the Trial Judge and also by the High Court.

facts.text: Their evidence was believed by the Trial Judge and also by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Their evidence was believed by the Trial Judge and also by the High Court. In support of the appeal it is companytended by Mr. Sethi that we should look at the evidence ourselves as the High Court does number appear to have taken into companysideration, in appreciating the evidence, the Characteristics of the injuries caused by the shot.

facts.text: Doctor's evidence: wound roundish, 1-1/2 x 1-1/4 communicating with the right chest cavity.

anchor.surface_text: The doctors evidence shows  1  that the wound caused was a roundish, wound 1-1/2x 1-1/4 companymunicating with the right chest cavity  2  that the wound was plugged with a companyk wadding and card board disc of 12 bore cartridge

facts.text: Wound was plugged with wadding and card board disc of 12 bore cartridge.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the wound was plugged with a companyk wadding and card board disc of 12 bore cartridge  3  that the right fourth and fifth ribs were blown off under the wound and also the right lung was punctured over an area 2-1/2x 2 about in its middle lobe about its interior margin in the middle which was blown off,

facts.text: Right fourth and fifth ribs were blown off under the wound and right lung punctured over an area 2-1/2x2.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the right fourth and fifth ribs were blown off under the wound and also the right lung was punctured over an area 2-1/2x 2 about in its middle lobe about its interior margin in the middle which was blown off,  4  that the woollen companyt, which was on the body of the deceased, was bloodstained with a companyresponding rent blackened charred the shirt was also blood stained with a companyresponding rent blackened.

facts.text: Woollen coat bloodstained with corresponding rent blackened charred; shirt blood stained with corresponding rent blackened.

anchor.surface_text: 4  that the woollen companyt, which was on the body of the deceased, was bloodstained with a companyresponding rent blackened charred the shirt was also blood stained with a companyresponding rent blackened. The doctor gave the opinion that the distance from which the shot was fired might be three to four feet.

facts.text: Doctor gave opinion that distance from which shot fired might be three to four feet.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor gave the opinion that the distance from which the shot was fired might be three to four feet. There was some cross-examination of the doctor in the Committing Court but the companyrectness of this opinion was number challenged.

facts.text: Doctor's deposition as recorded by the Committing Court was treated as evidence in the Sessions Court under s.509 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor did number appear to give evidence before the Sessions Court. His deposition as recorded by the Committing Court was treated as evidence in the Sessions Court under the provisions of s.509 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theory of death having been caused by a companytact shot it indicates that the shot was fired from about a yard away.

facts.text: Court concludes that shot was fired from about three to four feet away.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the features of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-in-chief, which was number challenged in cross- examination before the Committing Magistrate, that the shot may have been fired about three to four feet away should be accepted as companyrect.

facts.text: No reason to interfere with assessment of evidence by High Court and conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We find numberreason therefore interfere with the assessment of evidence as made by the High Court and also with the order, of companyviction and sentence passed by it.

The Appellant was companyvicted by the Sessions Judge, Patiala, of an offence under s.302 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gurdev Singh and sentenced to death. The Punjab High Court dismissed his appeal and companyfined the sentence of death.

concepts.interpretation: Court upholds conviction and death sentence for murder under s.302 IPC after re-examining evidence and finding no reason to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special Leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 890 of 1961 of Murder Reference No. 74 of 1961. Jai Gopal Sethi, C. L. Sareen and R. L. Kohli, for appellant.

The present appeal is on the strength of special granted by this Court. The prosecution case is that at about 2.30 p.m. on November 18, 1960 when Gurdev Singh was passing the tea-stall of Cbaran Singh, number far from the companyrts at Barnala on a motor cycle, the appellant Sewa Singh, who was at that time in that shop with a double barrel gun stood up and fired a shot at him.

The doctor did number appear to give evidence before the Sessions Court. His deposition as recorded by the Committing Court was treated as evidence in the Sessions Court under the provisions of s.509 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theory of death having been caused by a companytact shot it indicates that the shot was fired from about a yard away.

concepts.interpretation: Deposition recorded by Committing Court treated as evidence in Sessions Court.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n, we find stated at p. 279 thus- At a distance of 3 feet the shot mass begins to spread, the wound is an inch or slight

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions allowing deposition from committing magistrate to be used as evidence in sessions trial

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special Leave from the judgment and order dated October 25, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 890 of 1961 of Murder Reference No. 74 of 1961. Jai Gopal Sethi, C. L. Sareen and R. L. Kohli, for appellant.

concepts.unlisted_description: High Court reference for confirmation of death sentence

issues.text: Whether the features of the injury indicate that the shot which killed Gurdev Singh was fired from a very close range, not exceeding a few inches

anchor.surface_text: the features of the injury on which we are now asked to hold that the shot which killed Gurdev Singh was fired from a very close range, not exceeding a few inches. Even so, we have thought it proper to hear the Counsel on this question, as in our view these features ought ordinarily to be taken into consideration in assessing the value of the evidence of the eye-witnesses.

arguments.claim: The High Court did not take into consideration the characteristics of the injuries caused by the shot in appreciating the evidence, so this Court should look at the evidence itself.

anchor.surface_text: Their evidence was believed by the Trial Judge and also by the High Court. In support of the appeal it is contended by Mr. Sethi that we should look at the evidence ourselves as the High Court does not appear to have taken into consideration, in appreciating the evidence, the Characteristics of the injuries caused by the shot.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e a totally different version as regards the distance of the gun from the body of the victim. It has to be mentioned that the judgment of the High Cou

arguments.court_reasoning: Court notes High Court judgment contains no discussion on this point but decides to hear counsel as features ought to be considered in assessing eyewitness evidence.

arguments.claim: Features of the injury from doctor's evidence clearly show the gun was held in close contact with the body or within two or three inches.

anchor.surface_text: He has drawn our attention to a decision of this Court in Zora Singh v. The State of Punjab Criminal Appeal No. 81 of 1957 Judgment delivered on 10.5-1957 . According to the learned Counsel these features of the injury as they appear from the Doctors evidence clearly show that when the gun was fired it was held in close contact with the body of the victim or within two or three inches of it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r the provisions of s.509 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theor

arguments.court_reasoning: Court analyzes wound features using forensic texts and doctor's unchallenged opinion, concludes shot fired from about 3-4 feet away.

arguments.claim: Eyewitnesses did not actually see the occurrence as they give a totally different version of the distance of the gun from the body of the victim.

anchor.surface_text: This, argues the learned Counsel, shows that the witnesses who have claimed to have been the occurrence did not actually see the occurrence as they give a totally different version as regards the distance of the gun from the body of the victim.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: No reason to interfere with High Court's assessment of evidence after re-examination.

arguments.claim: Size of the wound (roundish 1-1/2 x 1-1/4) indicates shot fired from about a yard away, not contact shot.

anchor.surface_text: The doctors evidence shows 1 that the wound caused was a roundish, wound 1-1/2x 1-1/4 communicating with the right chest cavity 2 that the wound was plugged with a cork wadding and card board disc of 12 bore cartridge ... Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theory of death having been caused by a contact shot it indicates that the shot was fired from about a yard away.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: Supported by forensic authorities like Sidney Smith, Burrard, Lyons, Taylor.

arguments.claim: Doctor's opinion that distance was three to four feet is correct as not challenged in cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor gave the opinion that the distance from which the shot was fired might be three to four feet. There was some cross-examination of the doctor in the Committing Court but the correctness of this opinion was not challenged. The doctor did not appear to give evidence before the Sessions Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: Unchallenged in examination-in-chief before Committing Magistrate.

arguments.claim: Burning of clothes (blackened and charred) not indicative of shot from few inches.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that the burning of the clothes as described by the doctor is any indication that the shot was fired from within a few inches. Mr. Sethi has drawn our attention to the statement made in the several text books... According to this view therefore marks of burning may be found in the clothes or body of a person if the shot was fired at a distance of a yard or a yard and a half with a shot-gun.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Taylor's Principles: burning possible up to yard and a half with shotgun.

arguments.claim: Wad lodged in wound consistent with shot from about a yard.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary next to consider the fact that the cork was found lodged in the body... The fact that the wad was lodged in the wound appears therefore to be quite consistent with the shot having been fired from about a yard.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Glaister, Sidney Smith: wads enter in near discharges up to yard.

arguments.claim: Blowing off of ribs and lung better explained by wound size measurement than description; indicates 3-4 feet, not few inches.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider what the doctor has described as the blowing off of the ribs and a part of the right lung. ... As there is less likelihood of any mistake being made in the measurement of the wound than about the doctors view about the blowing off of the ribs., we are of opinion that what the doctor has described as blowing off is not a good reason for thinking that the shot was fired only a few inches off from the body.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atures of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-

arguments.court_reasoning: Prefer accurate wound measurement over descriptive 'blowing off'.

arguments.claim: No reason to interfere with High Court's assessment of evidence, conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of all the features of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have come to the conclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-in-chief... should be accepted as correct. We find no reason therefore interfere with the assessment of evidence as made by the High Court and also with the order, of conviction and sentence passed by it.

holdings.text: On a consideration of all the features of the wound as described by the doctor together, we have come to the conclusion that the doctor's opinion as given in his examination-in-chief, which was not challenged in cross-examination before the Committing Magistrate, that the shot may have been fired about three to four feet away should be accepted as correct.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the features of the wound as described by the doctors together, we have companye to the companyclusion that the doctors opinion as given in his examination-in-chief, which was number challenged in cross- examination before the Committing Magistrate, that the shot may have been fired about three to four feet away should be accepted as companyrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analyzed wound dimensions, embedded wad, clothing singe marks, and internal injuries using forensic texts (Sidney Smith, Burrard, Lyons, Taylor, Glaister) and unchallenged doctor's opinion, rejecting close-contact theory.

holdings.text: We find no reason to interfere with the assessment of evidence as made by the High Court and also with the order of conviction and sentence passed by it.

anchor.surface_text: We find numberreason therefore interfere with the assessment of evidence as made by the High Court and also with the order, of companyviction and sentence passed by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness credibility upheld after confirming medical evidence consistent with their account of firing distance; deference to High Court's evaluation absent perversity.

holdings.text: Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theory of death having been caused by a contact shot it indicates that the shot was fired from about a yard away.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor did number appear to give evidence before the Sessions Court. His deposition as recorded by the Committing Court was treated as evidence in the Sessions Court under the provisions of s.509 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Turning first to the size of the wound it appears to us that far from supporting the theory of death having been caused by a companytact shot it indicates that the shot was fired from about a yard away.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wound measured 1-1/2 x 1-1/4 inches, consistent with shotgun discharge at yard per Sidney Smith, Burrard, Lyons, Taylor.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree that the burning of the clothes as described by the doctor is any indication that the shot was fired from within a few inches.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that the burning of the clothes as described by the doctor is any indication that the shot was fired from within a few inches. Mr. Sethi has drawn our attention to the statement made in the several text books...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Singeing possible up to yard-and-a-half with shotgun per Taylor's Principles; no skin blackening noted.

holdings.text: The fact that the wad was lodged in the wound appears therefore to be quite consistent with the shot having been fired from about a yard.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary next to companysider the fact that the companyk was found lodged in the body... The fact that the wad was lodged in the wound appears therefore to be quite companysistent with the shot having been fired from about a yard.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wads enter wounds in near discharges up to yard per Glaister and Sidney Smith.

holdings.text: what the doctor has described as blowing off is not a good reason for thinking that the shot was fired only a few inches off from the body.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to companysider what the doctors has described as the blowing off of the ribs and a part of the right lung. ... As there is less likelihood of any mistake being made in the measurement of the wound than about the doctors view about the blowing off of the ribs., we are of opinion that what the doctor has described as blowing off is number a good reason for thinking that the shot was fired only a few inches off from the body.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prioritized precise wound measurement over descriptive internal damage assessment due to lower error risk.
